div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Herefordshire 7182 tons, Oct. 11.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, October 1.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Russian Stream Navigation & Commercial Company.
div.p: Postal Service Accelerated
between Alexandria, Piraeus, Smyrna, Constantinople, and Odessa by the following recenlty built and perfectly equipped vessels:
Arrivals at Alexandria on Saturday afternoons.
Departures from Alexandria on Fridays at 10 a.m. Circular route between Alexandria, Port Said, the Syrian ports, Chio, Smyrna, Mount Athos, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
Arrivals at Alexandria every other Monday early in the morning.
Departures from Alexandria on Wednesdays at 4 p.m.
Crimean or Bessarabian table wines free.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7a.m. Arrival Vinice every Wednesday about 8:30a.m. in time for xpressconnecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 15, 1906.

div.head: THE SWORD OF OTHMAN
div.p: The irony of fate has made the weal or woe of an Empire dependent on the knife of a surgeon. Upon the success of Dr, Bergmann has hung, like the Sword of Damocles, the future of Turkey.

The present is a critical time not only for that land of two continents, but for Europe as well, and this owing to the complex and shifting base of international relations in the Near East. With Russia in a foment of insurrection, the Balkan States squabbling over Macedonia the revival of the Cretan agitation; in Asia, the troubles in Persia, wars and rumours of wars throughout Arabia, to say nothing of the apparent deadlock in the Sinai boundary negotiations, and finally, the Tripoli Question—these and many other phases of Eastern politics, ugly enough as as they are, would have become even more so in the eyes of interested spectators had that surgical operation terminated fatally. In the interests of all that tends to peace, it is earnestly to be prayed that the Sultan may long be spared to preside over the affairs of Eastern Europe.

"Padishahimir tchok yaeha ' ("Long Life To our Sultan") is an exclamation in which not only loyal Turks but European statesmen may very well join. For all the ill-feeling and opposition with which his policy encounters, there is no gainsaying the fact that the unique statecraft and masterly intelligence of His Imperial Majesty would in the event of his untimely demise-which Allah forbade—create a void that it would be hard to fill. Whatever may be said to the contrary by pro Armenians and renegade Young Turks, for whose fatuous vapourings abroad the Turkish vocabulary has provided an excellent epithet, that of bosh boghazlar ('empty mouths'),despite the disciples of the (Gladstonian superstition, it is an axiom of European politics which is undeniable that the bolstering up of Turkey,and the firm establishment of the Sultan at Constantinople, is a vital necessity, as essential to the European status quo, as is the Sun Canal to our world- position. The recent prospect, happily we hope dissipated, of a succession to the Throne of the Caliphate, has been one therefore of European concern, not because of the fear of a national upheaval -for Turkey has seen strange things without the mass of her conservative population being in any way disturbed-but for the peace of Europe. During the recent crisis, it was natural that the question of who should succeed Abdul Hamid should arise. According to the old law of succession established by Othman. The eldest brother of the reigning family succeeds. Salim I., the third son of Bayasid II., who usurped the Throne and Caliphate in 1520, or 926 of the Hedjira, parted with this tradition, by naming his eldest son as his successor , and this order of direct lineal descent was sanctioned and sealed by the innocent blood of lawful heirs whose existence was dangerous to this principle, and whose earthly remains repots in a shrine which steads within the shadow of St. Sophia in Stamboul. This went until the death in 1617 of Ahmed I. when possibly to spare the live, of four brothers the Council of Ministers and the Ulema proclaimed Mustapha 1, his brother, who owed his life and throne to an affected actual imbecility. Mustapha I. died within the year of his accession, and Osman II , the eldest son of Ahmed I., was girded with the Sword of Ottman in 1618, since when the institution of Selim I. has prevailed Custom became law, hat it mast also he remembered that the bam of the Caliphate permit the exercise of a prerogative whereby the Padishah may choose a successor out of his own family, subject however to the approval of the nation, -a condition which has never been observed. According to this order of succession, then, it it Knhad Bflondi, the Sultan's invalid brother, who should succeed; but in view of his physical incapacity, the Throne would go to Youssouf Izzodin, son of Abdul Asia.

This was an arrangement suggested last year with a view of appeasing European curiosity Symptoms point to Prince Burhaneddin. the Sultan's favourite son, as his successor designate, and it was not so long ago that Hikmet Pasha, one of the Palace functionaries, was sent to gather the opinion of the Courts of Europe regarding such an arrangement.
Always order LIEBIG as
LEMCO
The original Liebig Company's Extract of Beef.
The Plague Today a plague bulletin records no fresh cases but two recoveries at Mallawi.
Maieh Sanieh. A native contemporary states that it is intended to appoint an English Adviser to the Maieh Sanieh.
Fashn Markaz. The Ministry of the Interior has decided to separate Nahiet El-Massit from Fashn Markaz and place it under the administration of Maghagha Markaz.
Rotations. Owing to this year's good floods orders have been given in the Moudiriehs of Sharkieh and Galioubieh and the district of Mit Ghamr to cease the rotations on the canals.

Doctor Attempts Suicide. A native doctor, who is mentally afflicted, attempted to commit suicide yesterday by stabbing himself with a knife is the neck. He was taken to hospital. The wound is stated to be not fatal.
Blue Nile Moudirieh. Yousbashi Abdel Ghani Eff Fuad has been appointed Hakamdar of Police is the Blue Nile Moudirieh, vice Yousbashi Mohamed Eff. Human, who has been transferred to the Egyptian Army.

Fatal Railway Accident. On Monday morning, a native woman and her little child, whom she was carrying, were run over by a light railway tram at Kom el Akhdar, Abou Hommos Marker Hehera, and were both killed the spot.

San Stefano Theatre. A French comedy company will make its debut at the San Stefano Theatre to-morrow evening with the two act comedy Bonbomaroche. The vocal part of the programme will include Mila Deparme and Mlle Mary Fieuri.

Building Lands of Egypt. It is rumoured that there is to be some opposition to the tension of the Egyptian Trust and Investment by the Building Lands of Egypt owing to certain alleged irregularities in the voting. An explanation will be found in to-day's 'Bourse Bulletin.'

Alexandria Vlema Board The annual examination of the students in the Alexandria mosques will be held on Saturday next by the Ulema Board of Alexandria under the presidency of Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, who will distribute prizes and monetary rewards to the successful 'Talaba.'

Drowning Accident. The body of a native was found floating in the Nile opposite Keneh a few days ago, and taken out by some sailors, who took the body to the hospital. On examination it was found that the dead man had 8 in his purse and a gold watch. His seal indicated that his name was Ahmed And Alle. The post-mortem showed that he had been drowned accidentally.

Egyptian Shorthand. A middle-aged man with long hair and spectacles, says the "New York Press," of the ind alto. went round and round the Obelisk in Central Park, bankbook in hand, making notes with a pencil. When he sat down to rest one who had been watching him asked the purpose of his memoranda. "Oh, just a fancy of mine," he replied. "I believe that most of the hieroglyphics of Egypt are a sort of advanced shorthand, and am making a study of the principle." Is that man sane or insane?

Wanted-Mosquitos The Mississippi Board of Health reports that the new mosquito, instead of being a drug on the market, as it is ordinarily at this season of the year, is almost in demand because of its scarcity. Science is hot after the mosquitos. Huntsmen and civilization have driven the bear and the panther farther into the wilds, the buffalo is almost extinct. can it be that science is following thus relentlessly the mosquitos! Will we one day look upon the specimen as a curiosity?- "Commercial Appeal," Memphis (U.S.A).

New Employment Registry. The British chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary. British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH. REPORTED TO BE BETTER
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, August 14.
The Sultan is well again. (Haze)

Nouri Bey, secretary to H. E. Gbazi, Mukhtar Pasha. telegraphed to "Al Moayad" yesterday stating that H. I. M. the Sultan had been, con- fined to bed owing to a slight cold. His Majesty however, has now quite recovered, and is enjoying excellent health.

div.head: CAIRO MOTOR FATALITY MOUDIR'S WIFE KILLED
div.p: On Monday evening, Yasin Bey Mustafa, Moudir of Keneh, and his wife were motoring in Sharia K Abhara, Cairo, when their anto- mobile collided with a cart laden with timber Mme Yassin Bay was struck by a piece of wood on the breast and so severely injured that she fell dead almost instantly. The Moudir also received serious injuries.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S ESHESHES
div.p: The last report of the Municipal Delegation bows that the great question of the "eshesh es," situated in various part of Alexandria, is again occupying the serious attention of the Municipality.

We understand that Suleiman Abani Bey has presented a really remarkable report on the subject to the Delegation. This report was received with unanimous approval by the members, and a sub-committee was immediately selected to go into the who's question and to consult with the Government is order to avoid any loss of time in coming to some practical conclusion on this subject which so vitally affects the interests of the tows from a hygienic point of view.

One of the most pressing questions is that of the native burial ground near Pompey's Pillar, and it is becoming urgent the the land occupied by what are known as the Toubgseh esheshes should be reorganized in this cemetery in order to allow natives intermediate to be conducted with decency Yurtbermore there are several other agencies of esheshes such as them of Gabbiest, Chatby and other quarters, which call for a prompt solution.

We have no doubt that the Egyptian Government will start the Alexandria Mult plicity half way and will have with mult plicity is embarassing to something the state of things now escalating.which is always a problem with public health.
The sub commites, which are now examining the questions is Mr.Amillio, Mr. George Zander, and MR.Ambri Kali.

div.head: MORALITY CRUSADE. PAST AND PRESENT CAMPAIGNS
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, The campaign against sexual impu- rity in the a streets, which Miralai Hopkinson Bey has undertaken in the best interests of Alexandria, deserves the approbation of all good men. About twenty six years ago I began a similar work la connection with the Church of Scotland and was in receipt of enough funds to send the women back to their own coun- tries. But the scheme fell through finally through lack of means. An Irish lady. Mrs. R H P Doran, subsequently resumed the work of purity log Alexandria, and also tried to take steps to save the women not only from an immoral life but from physical destrue- tion. This lady still sends me funds for that purpose. Other philanthropic ladies in Germany, Austria, and England have, on pass ing through Alexandria in the tourist season, asked me what measures are being taken in this work, but the only lady who has rendered devoted service to the cause, is Mr. Sheldon Amos. She acompanied me to the haunts of vice in our city and by her exhortations and sympathy did her utmost to interest other people is the purification of Alexandria. Mr Claude Moutefiora two years ago also took an interest in the work and consulted me on the subject through the introduction of Baron Jarques de Menaace. Since then an International Association was formed, but as the members had no expe- erience of this work the whole duty fell on Miralai Hopkinson Bey and myself, who were the only persons who had any practical ex- perience of how to save girls from a vicious life. The work of the association was not carried on properly and so i resigned and since then I was obliged to write to Lord Cromer to tell him how matters had been mismanaged. Now the work is under police management and there is really no need for the existance of the International Associa- tion. Miralai Hopkinson Bey has been most successful in his campaign against fast women and his endurance to raise the moral tone of Alexandria should be succeeded by all the members of the population. am etc,
Peter Rudolph "The Rudolph House" Alexandria 15th August

div.head: THE CAPITLATIONs.
REPLY TO "XENOS"
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,-In a recent issue of your valuable paper, there appeared a letter by "Xenoa" on a subject to which he is very much a stranger. At first, on reading the triple head-line, I was led to believe that a serious obstacle had been found to the realisation of the scema propound- ed by Lord Cromer for ridding Egypt of the bane of the Capitulations. I had not proceed- ed very far however before I realised that the writer was hopelessly astray. Indeed, the arti- cle is such a tissue of palpable inacouracies that it were not worth while refuting them did not the importance of the subject warrant the removal of any misapprehensions which may exist in the minds of those who have not stu- died Lord Cromer's project.

In the first place, I fail to see why any opposition whatever--still less opposition "of the most determined kind"- to the abolition of the Capitulations should come from the Greek Orthodox community "subject to the essential authority of the Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, as distinguished from the Hel- lenc colony under the rule of the Hellenic Diplomatic Agency and Consulate General." "Xenos" obviously refers to the "Rayahs," or Greek local subjects. Now the most cursory examination of Lord Cromer's project will show that its fundamental feature is the abolition of the Mixed Tribunals and the Consular jurisdictions, and that it will only affect sub- jects of a European Power so far as regards civil and criminal affairs, matters of personal states not coming within the scope of the project.

All religious courts--that is, courts which deal with matters of personal status such as the Mchkeweh Sharieh, the Fatriaruhates, Bishoprice and Rebbinal courts, will ocntines to exercise the same powers as he enforce, and therefore I cannot understand in what way the Greek Patriarchate, any more than any other Patriarchate, should "ove by the transaction both in authority and immorial prestige" (sic.) "Xenos" tells us that as a consequence of the change "the mass of these Rsyshs subject to its canons will either, as Ottoman(1) subjects, find themselves subject regaurding their evil affairs to Egyptian control" (What amazing ignorance! As Rayahs they are and always will be subject to Egyptian control in evil matters)--"or they will possibly petition the power to secede to the authority of the Hellenic Conpulate General." Now isn't that real nice of them! How, if all consular jerietition is to be abolished, and not Patriarchial, could they, or should they, succede to the Consultant General. This letter alternative, "Xenos" naively informs us, is most likely as "already it is adopted by the majority of Greek Ottomess subjects arriving in Egypt." The patriarchate has no civil jurisdiction, argo that is impossible. I find however in the following paragraph of his letter that "Xenos" is hopefully at ese as to what constitutes civil matters for he proceeds to give a curious definition, i.e. divorce, predate of will and all other matters whereis the patriarchial seal is neccessary. Was there ever such as elastic phrase! "Xenos" (who should know better after consulting "a high dignitary of the church") of course reform to matters of personal states, and so I have before said, these will set he affected in any way by the abilities of the Capitulations. There will be on need for the Orthodox Greek community to fly to the protection of the King of Halles, a step which is, whenever , mmodered absolutley impossible by the scheme under consideration.

Evidently the Patriarch himself does not take such an alternative view of the situation, for us the authority of "Xenos" himself we learn that his atitude demonstrates a pleasure trip to Tripol and Tunis if only he can process the Imperical sanction to his during an. I enhance my card and remeber, Yours faithfully, "Xenopriore" Cales, 11th August, 1906

div.head: EGYPT AND THE PARLIAMENT.
THE ATTACK ON MR.FINDLAY.
HOME PRESS JUDGMENT.
div.p: Mi. Findlay is under a great debt of gratitude to Sir Bdward Urey for heriug deoided to incorporate the former's telegram from Alexandria of Joly 5th in the White Book on the Deoishwai affair. Had that docu- ment bean allowed to dumber in the pigeon t holes of the Foreign office the British CbargA d'Affaire* would to moot people bare been Still a magui nominie umbra. but owing to Sir Edward Grey's action he has beoome t tamoua, is at'ached by Little Euglanders, oom plimeoted hy the Foreign Secretary as "a man of charaeter and ability." and has earned the undying gratitude of Egyptian jonrneliata, for By having acouaed them of taking bribes he has enabled them to fill columns and columns of their nawapapers with protestationse, recrimi- nations, and polemics at a season of the year which is the dead waste and middle of the night so far as news in Egypt is concerned
The Opposition Prees have seized on Mr. Robertson's attack on Mr. Findlay with avidity and worked themselves into a fi e frenzy of indiguation.

div.head: What the "Times" thinks.
div.p: The "Times" says:-- Typical of much which has taken place since the Session opened was the maligrant outburst of hysterical invective against the officials of the Egyptian Govern- ment, or which Mr. J. M. Robertson made himself guilty. His mischievous and irresponaible fanatioion seems to have been roused to special fury by a telegram from one of Lord Cromer's aubordinates, Mr Findlay, in which the letter pointed out the probable effects of Parliamentary discussion upon public opinion in Egypt -- a telagram which Mr Robertson described as a "presumptuous censure" on the House of Commons by an "incompetent bureau- crat." After reading Mr.Robertson's speech we can only share Mr Findlay's anxiety. A member of Parliment wno can waive aside the brutal murder of one British officer. and the ill-treatment of others, as "a display of want of due raepent." provoked by what the villagers might well have considered an aat of trespass, and on the other hand denounces the punish- ment of the murderers by a Court composed of the highest legal authoritites in Egypt as "wholesale slaughter" and as a resort to "methods of barbarism," is, indeed, a danger to the public. Such language, especially when reported in the Egyptian Press, amounts to nothing less than a deliberate justification of murder and a wanton ineitament to fresh outbreaks. Mr. Edward Grey in his reply ad- ministered a dignified and crushing rebuke to the author of this mischevious tirade. He pointed out that the general adoption of such a tone by the House af Commons would make it quite impossible to conduct the business of the British Empire. He defended Mr Findlay's telegram, as sent purely for information and in no way intended as a censure on the House of Commons. He brushed aside Mr. Robertson's ridiculous denunciation of the "man on the spot" as always wrong, but pointed out how is the case of Egypt the question of the respon- sibility of the "man on the spot" is complicated by the peculiar character of the metheds whereby we direct the policy and influenmce the administration of the country

div.head: The Little Englander.
div.p: The "Globe" remarks:--It must be extreme- ly painful to Sir Edward Gret to reflect that the Administration of which he is such a distin- guished ornament, depends for its existence upon the support of people holding the views of Mr. J. M. Robertson, Mr. Arnold Luoton, and Mr. Byles. The display which the first named offered to an amused House of Commons on Saturday drew from the For- eign Secretary a dignified protest against the assumptions which is made by people of this sortthat British officials are always and everywhere in the wrong; but it is not likely that the rebuke will havethe slightest effect Mr. Robertson found it impossible to refer to the Denishwai executions without talking about "cowardly, panic-stricken, officials" and "incompetent bureauocrats," and condemining a necessary act of justice as though it were a personal revenge for some trivial insult. For native treacherously to kill an English officer who had done them no measure of harm is, according to Mr. Robert- son, not murder at all, but only a form of homiside which, we gather, is hardly capable. For English soldiers to defend them- selves with the arms supplied to them against changing Zulus is not fair fighting. accordig to the egregious Byles, and is, therefore, we suppose, something very like murder. If the public will put those two conceptions together, and will appreciate the fact that these Byles and Robertsons all act together to belittle the power of Eng- land, and to blemish the fair fame of her trusted servants, the true state of affairs we be, perhaps, more clearly evident than it has been. We notice they are terribly tender about the flogging of ruffiance who most justly deserve a penalty much more severe. We only wish they had the courage to share in every particular the fortunes of their friends. A short turn on the triangles would, no doubt, be painful, but it would be extremly wholesome, and it might result in the abruption through the skin of a little patriotism and commerce.

div.head: The True Faith.
div.p: The "Fall Mall Gazette" says:-- It is a good thing that Mr. J. M. Robertson should have made his speech on Egyptian affairs on a day when there was nothing else to occupy the attention of the House of Commons, lecaure it gives everyone a chance of realising the true Radical conception of Imperial questions. Mr. Robertson makes no secret of his view that the typical British official is either a fool or a knave, that the "man on the spot" is disquali- fied by his situation from forming a sound judgement, and that countries like Egypt can only be safelt ruled from Tooley-street and in accordance with the doctrines which the Tooley- street environment engenders. For the present we have a Foreign Secretary who defies Tooley-street and its opinions, and Sir Edward Grey replied to Mr.Robertson's speech in lan- guage that might have been used by Lord Lausdowne or any Unionist Minister. But it is doubtful how long Sir Edward Grey will be able to maintain the independece which has been surrendered by the other "Liberal Impa" in the Cabinet, and when he has been subdued or got rid of we shall have a working exhibition of true Radicalism in foreign policy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The mortal remains of the late Mohamad Cherif art expactod to arrira at Alexan- dria oo tha Slat in»t. Tbt lata ex 8acratary of State for Foreign Affairs shortly before his dtath made a will bequeathing one third of bit estates to his wife
M. Rikakit, first secrtary to the Hellenic Diplomatic Agency and Oonualat: General, Cairo, who has been appoiottd Hellenic Consul- General it Yanina, will shortly leave for his new post.

The marriage took place a few days ago at Vienna of M Tbdotokia, son of the Hellenic Prime Minister, to Mile Achillopoulos, who belongs to a rich Greek family in Egypt M. Tbdotokis son., was prevented through the political situation from attending the marriage. His son, who has been hitherto an Attache to Ithe Paris Legislation, is about to enter as secretary to the Hellenic Legation in Vienna.

Beneducci Bey, secretary to the Governor of Alexandria yesturdat presented the beirat of Cousul to M. d'Abars, the new Russian Consul in Alexandria, after the document, had been registered in the Mehkemeh Sharieh.

H.I.M. the Shah of Persia has conferred the Order of Shir Khorshid of the 1st Class, on Dr. Issa Pasha Hamdi, who dedicated to his Majesty his Arabie work on internal dises- es, Ahmed Gamal Bey, the suthor's son, has also recieved the same Order of the 3rd class.
Rev. Canon and Mrs. Ward arrived at Alexandria this morning, on their return from England.
We regret to announce the death, which took place at Maraeilles on the 19th inst., of M. Xenophen Contantinides.
Mr. Joseph Frangi, the well-known Alexandria broker, died this morning. As a mark of respect the Bourse was closed for a quater of an hour.
Lieut. Col.G. R. Atkinson, A.O.D. has been granted leave of absense to October 3, with permission to travel in Turkey, Greese, Rou- mania, Bulgaria, and Servia.
Major James F. Donegan, R.A.M.C., has been promoted to the rank of lieut. colonel, and Lieut. Col. A.W. Roper, R.E, has been granted the brevet of colonel.

The following officers of the 1st Batta- lion Lancashire Fusillers have benn granted leave of absence for the 2 1/2 month:--Major H.S. Hamilton, Collison Morley, T. E. L. Maunaell, A.J.W. Bieneowa, and H. C, Smith.
Lieut John W. F. Turleton, 6th (luniskil- ling) Pusiliers, has been promoted Captain, vice Captain S.C. Bull, Whose tragic death is within the memory of all.
Lieut. Henry Beaumout, the Lancashire Pusiliers, has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army.

div.head:
POPE AND SEPARATION.
ELIPTICAL TO FRENCH BISHOPS

div.p: The Pope's Enoyolical to the French Bishops orders the clergy to disregaurd the law of seps ration as much as possile, also to ignore parochial associations, authorized under the Act to take over the charge of Church affairs.

The Enoyolical indicates that the Pope would prefer separation pure and simple to the present law. He recommends firmness and deprecates violence in the French Catholics struggle for the Church. He disclaims an anti repunlicn animus and throw the responsibi- lity for the present situation on the secularists. The Bishops have replied acuiescing. (R.)

The Pope's Enoyolical to the Church in France declares that the parochial associations are inacceptable, and calls upon Catholics to fight energetically for the defence of the reli- gion, but without viloence or sedition. (Fames)
The king has started for Marienbad. The newspapers emphasize the non political character of His Majesty's meeting with the Emperor William. (Hunter)
The Emperor William has gone to Frie- drichshof, where the interview with King Edward will take place. (Hamse)
Trains returning here, crowded with Sunday exoursionists, hav been stopped and searched by troops. 50 arrests have been made. (Heater)

A Ukase of the Governor General threfore with secare punishment employers who pay strikers during a strike, also of inhabitators who fail to inform the authorities against Terrorists whom they hand over money under threats of death. The Ukase has caused a panic since compliance with its demands is impos- sible. (Remster)
